message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an infection, and the expressible purulence coming from his wound confirms it. Among the options, only neutrophils have abundant peroxidase-positive granules, and a peripheral blood smear would most likely reveal this finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the patient suggest osteomyelitis or septic arthritis, which are usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Among the options, only option C describes neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules, which are characteristic of bacterial infection. Option A describes Chronic Granulomatous Disease, option B describes Vitamin B12 deficiency, and option D describes Pelger-Huët anomaly, all of which are not likely in this patient's case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of acute bacterial arthritis, and the presence of expressible purulence from the wound supports this. Neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules are characteristic of acute bacterial infections. Option A is associated with chronic granulomatous disease, Option B is associated with liver disease, and option D is not a recognized finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of easy bruising and bleeding gums, which suggests underlying bleeding disorder. The red and swollen elbow also suggests bacterial infection. The presence of purulence coming from the wound suggests a bacterial abscess. The most likely finding on a peripheral blood smear would be neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules, indicating an acute bacterial infection. Option A refers to chronic granulomatous disease, Option B refers to liver disease, and Option D refers to a form of leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms including fever, pain, swelling, and purulence suggest a bacterial infection, most likely Staphylococcus aureus. Neutrophils are the primary cells that respond to bacterial infections, and they contain abundant peroxidase-positive granules. Option A (absence of dark blue cytoplasmic staining) is characteristic of chronic granulomatous disease, which is unlikely in this case. Option B (macrocytic erythrocytes and acanthocytes) is seen in liver disease or lipid metabolism disorders, which are also unlikely in this case. Option D (neutrophils with peroxidase-negative granules) is characteristic of eosinophils, which are not expected to be elevated in a bacterial infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of easy bruising and bleeding gums, which suggests a possible bleeding disorder. The symptoms and signs in the elbow suggest a bacterial infection, likely with Staphylococcus aureus. Peripheral blood smear findings are suggestive of neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules indicating an acute bacterial infection. Options A and B are not relevant to the given presentation, and option D describes a rare condition called specific granule deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the fever and purulent wound, suggest an infection, and the history of easy bruising and bleeding gums suggests a possible bleeding disorder. Among the options, only (C) neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules describe normal neutrophil function and would be expected in a patient with an infection. The absence of dark blue cytoplasmic staining upon nitroblue tetrazolium administration (Option A) is seen in patients with chronic granulomatous disease, macrocytic erythrocytes and acanthocytes (Option B) are seen in patients with liver disease or lipid metabolism disorders, and neutrophils with peroxidase-negative granules (Option D) are seen in patients with specific abnormalities in their granules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of easy bruising and bleeding gums indicates a possible bleeding disorder. The symptoms and signs suggest the patient has a joint infection. Peripheral blood smear in this patient would most likely reveal neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules, indicating an active infection. Options A and B are not relevant and Option D suggests a rare condition called Pelger-Huët anomaly which is not likely in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest an infection, and the purulence from the wound supports this. Neutrophils are the main cells responsible for fighting off bacterial infections and they have peroxidase-positive granules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The easy bruising and bleeding gums suggest a possible bleeding disorder, which can be seen in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), a rare genetic disorder causing recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. Among the options, only (C) Neutrophils with abundant peroxidase-positive granules is associated with CGD. The patient may have developed an abscess at the site of the scrape and may require surgical drainage and antibiotic therapy.
